item.title: Mullvad VPN and Lockdown mode
item.dc:creator: @JustPassinThru
item.description:
I removed the entire MullvadVPN from sysmaint. It was a horrible idea. But I do use it on user side and run Whonix thru it

Also, I have an HP Elitebook for my KickSecure/Whonix setup. Its working fine

I did try updating via CLI, it ran into xscreensaver issues and locked me out so I had to do a fresh install on bare metal

Life with Linux

item.title: Virtualbox installers stopped working
item.dc:creator: @shaylabeige
item.description:
Yesterday i had no problem with the installer that was recommended, but today I span brand new clean VM which i always do when i test new setups for when things break like this. And I tested 8 methods of installing 7 of which produced errors. I had to remove all the links so it might be a bit unintelligible. If you want o read with links the pastebin is XC638Aku

Method’s 1, 2, 3 and 4 produced the same Error:
[sysmaint ~]% bash ./virtualbox-installer-clivirtualbox-installer-cli:
[ERROR]: Directory doesn’t exist: ‘/home/user’virtualbox-installer-cli:
[ERROR]: Aborting.virtualbox-installer-cli:
[NOTICE]: Executed script, function, command executed: ‘./virtualbox-installer-cli’ ‘die’ ‘exit “${1}”’virtualbox-installer-cli:
[ERROR]: Installer exited with code: ‘1’zsh: exit 1 bash ./virtualbox-installer-cli
(Same Directory doesn’t exist: ‘/home/user’ etc)

Method: 1
kicksecure-lxqt-installer-cli
kicksecure-lxqt-installer-cli --onion

Method 2
curl --tlsv1.3 --output virtualbox-installer-cli --url kicksecure. /dist-installer-clibash ./virtualbox-installer-cli

Method 3:
curl --tlsv1.3 --output kicksecure-lxqt-installer-cli --url kicksecure /dist-installer-cli
bash ./virtualbox-installer-cli --onion

Method 4:
bash ./virtualbox-installer-cli --oracle-repo

Method 5:
sudo apt update
sudo apt install --no-install-recommends virtualbox-qt
sudo adduser $(whoami) vboxusers

Producess Error:
Unsatisfied dependencies:
virtualbox-qt : Depends: virtualbox (= 7.2.2-dfsg-2) but it is not installable
Error: Unable to correct problems, you have held broken packages.
Error: The following information from --solver 3.0 may provide additional context:
Unable to satisfy dependencies. Reached two conflicting decisions:

  1. virtualbox-qt:amd64=7.2.2-dfsg-2 is selected for install
  2. virtualbox-qt:amd64 Depends virtualbox (= 7.2.2-dfsg-2)
    but none of the choices are installable:
    [no choices]
    zsh: exit 100 sudo apt install --no-install-recommends virtualbox-qt

Method 6 :

sudo apt update && sudo apt full-upgrade

sudo apt install --no-install-recommends extrepo

sudoedit /etc/extrepo/config.yaml

  • contrib
  • non-free

sudo extrepo enable virtualbox

sudo apt update

sudo apt install virtualbox-7.2 linux-headers-$(uname -r)

Produces error: The file does not exist. And doesnt let me save the changes

Method 7:
Paste the whole text:

echo “Types: deb
URIs:
Suites: $(lsb_release -sc)
Components: contrib
Enabled: yes
Signed-By: /usr/share/keyrings/virtualbox-archive-keyring.asc” | sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/virtualbox.sources

curl --tlsv1.3 --remote-name --tlsv1.2

gpg --keyid-format long --import --import-options show-only --with-fingerprint oracle_vbox_2016.asc

Verify the fingerprint.
The most important check is confirming the key fingerprint exactly matches the output below.
Key fingerprint = B9F8 D658 297A F3EF C18D 5CDF A2F6 83C5 2980 AECF

sudo cp oracle_vbox_2016.asc /usr/share/keyrings/virtualbox-archive-keyring.asc

sudo apt update

sudo apt install virtualbox-7.2 linux-headers-$(uname -r)

Produces Error:
Get:1 trixie InRelease [4,440 B]
Err:1 trixie InRelease
Sub-process /usr/bin/sqv returned an error code (1), error message is: Error: Failed to parse keyring “/usr/share/keyrings/virtualbox-archive-keyring.asc” Caused by: 0: Reading “/usr/share/keyrings/virtualbox-archive-keyring.asc”: Permission denied (os error 13) 1: Permission denied (os error 13)
Hit:2 tor+://deb.kicksecure. trixie InRelease
Hit:3 tor+://fasttrack.debian .net/debian-fasttrack trixie-fasttrack InRelease
Hit:4 tor+://fasttrack.debian. net/debian-fasttrack trixie-backports-staging InRelease
Hit:5 tor+://deb.debian. org/ debian trixie InRelease
Hit:6 tor+://deb.debian. org/debian trixie-updates InRelease
Hit:7 tor+://deb.debian .org/debian trixie-backports InRelease
Hit:8 tor+://deb.debian .org/debian-security trixie-security InRelease
Warning: OpenPGP signature verification failed: trixie InRelease: Sub-process /usr/bin/sqv returned an error code (1), error message is: Error: Failed to parse keyring “/usr/share/keyrings/virtualbox-archive-keyring.asc” Caused by: 0: Reading “/usr/share/keyrings/virtualbox-archive-keyring. asc”: Permission denied (os error 13) 1: Permission denied (os error 13)
Error: The repository ‘ trixie InRelease’ is not signed.
Notice: Updating from such a repository can’t be done securely, and is therefore disabled by default.
Notice: See apt-secure(8) manpage for repository creation and user configuration details.
zsh: exit 100 sudo apt update
The links were removed so i can post but they ware towards debian repository

Method 8: Is the only one that works for me for now

$ sudo apt install curl wget gnupg2 lsb-release -y
$ curl -fsSL gpg --dearmor -o /etc/apt/trusted.gpg.d/vbox.gpg
$ curl -fsSL gpg --dearmor -o /etc/apt/trusted.gpg.d/oracle_vbox.gpg

$ echo “deb [arch=amd64] $(lsb_release -cs) contrib” | sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/virtualbox.list

$ sudo apt update
$ sudo apt install linux-headers-$(uname -r) dkms -y
$ sudo apt install virtualbox-7.2 -y

$ sudo usermod -aG vboxusers $USER
$ newgrp vboxusers

$ wget download.virtualbox./virtualbox/7.2.4/Oracle_VirtualBox_Extension_Pack-7.2.4.vbox-extpack

$ sudo vboxmanage extpack install Oracle_VirtualBox_Extension_Pack-7.2.4.vbox-extpack

vboxmanage --version
sudo apt remove --purge virtualbox-7.2
sudo apt autoremove
sudo apt autoremove virtualbox

Success

item.title: Start up is a little strange for me in version 18
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
trizzo:

Can I flash a USB with kicksecure 18?

I think you’re talking about installing Kicksecure to a USB drive the way you’d install it onto an internal hard disk? If so, yes, this is supported and documented:

Kicksecure – 18 Dec 25

Installation of Kicksecure on a USB

Yes, Kicksecure can be installed on a USB. Here's how.

(Note: You’ll want to boot into LIVE Mode | UNRESTRICTED Session when booting from the ISO to make the instructions here work as written. It looks like this wiki page needs some minor updates.)

thanks!

item.description:

No. Maybe in the next major version. Depending on LXQt / labwc or whatever desktop environment will be the thing at that time.

item.title: Ram-wipe no longer functional in Kicksecure 18?
item.dc:creator: @trizzo
item.description:
Dude! You’re and absolute LEGEND!! Thank you!

Also I kinda like the new shutdown sequence more than the old one.

Yeah nah I like what you’ve done, again, the redesign is cool and I like how the battery symbol now has the percentage number on it too. Lots of small minor quality of life improvements!

I know you said to go to another thread, but may I ask if there’s any plans to implement the desktop switcher anytime soon?

Thanks again man

item.title: Ram-wipe no longer functional in Kicksecure 18?
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
trizzo:

Also it doesn’t say when I start up my laptop that ram-wipe is on.

Indeed. I removed that. There are no more visual indicators during boot. Updated wiki chapter Boot Printout just now.

But that reminds me… [1]

trizzo:

So you reckon it still works?

Thanks to third-party security audit, ram-wipe security-audit by 3MDEB in 2025, this can be labeled Reasonable Security.

trizzo:

I’m just not sure what I’m looking for with ram-wipe.

[1] It could be very hard for laymen users to confirm functionality. There is one thing you might be able to see. → Shutdown Printout

But these messages will probably appear so fast and the reboot/shutdown is so fast that can most people probably will have reasonable chance to read messages. One simple “trick” could be to video record the shutdown process with camera and then watch/pause the recording.

For Advanced Users, at least a basic review using a serial console is possible. There are some pointers here: ram-wipe Functionality Testing

Otherwise if messages are appearing to fast, developers locally for example inject sleep commands into the code or inject a shell.

Full review can be done by developers / expert. The test methodology had been fully documented during the 3MDEB security-misc audit.

Related:

Kicksecure – 18 Aug 25

System Audit

Verifying the system is configured as intended

item.title: Ram-wipe no longer functional in Kicksecure 18?
item.dc:creator: @trizzo
item.description: Oh! Also it doesn’t say when I start up my laptop that ram-wipe is on. You know when you start up your laptop and ram-wipe would usually indicate it’s running. Now I’m not getting any indicator that it’s running.

item.title: Start up is a little strange for me in version 18
item.dc:creator: @trizzo
item.description:
Hi. I recently updated Kicksecure to version 18. The start up sequence is strange. I’m not a coder or anything, and have very little knowledge but I’ll explain briefly what’s happening to me.

When I turn on my laptop, it goes to the boot options (persistent, live mode, etc.). If I select either live mode or persistent, things start up normally, however when it comes to the part where I need to type in my password, for some reason the console freaks out and creates a loop of text (again, I’m sorry for being vague, as with such little knowledge I don’t know how to explain these things). Now in the midst of this strange loop of text, if I type my password in, it works and logs me in. Just a little strange, I can still access my computer and all, it’s just really weird.

Thanks

item.title: Ram-wipe no longer functional in Kicksecure 18?
item.dc:creator: @trizzo
item.description:
Ah ok thanks, yeah I’m a novice user and am only used to seeing a bunch of stars generate. So you reckon it still works? I’m just not sure what I’m looking for with ram-wipe.

Thanks

item.dc:creator: @Patrick

  • Start up sequence is weird, loops around and around until I type my passphrase in, then it works

item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
trizzo:
  1. The panel doesn’t intelligently hide when I select the option for it to hide when a window overlaps.

Should be the same as on Debian with LXQt / labwc.

This you can try to solve as per:

Kicksecure – 6 Sep 24

Potential Solutions Beyond Kicksecure!

Explore resources outside of Kicksecure to address unspecific questions or issues.

Kicksecure – 18 May 25

Self Support First Policy for Kicksecure

Definition of the Self Support First Policy for Kicksecure

Otherwise, please create a separate forum thread.

item.title: Ram-wipe no longer functional in Kicksecure 18?
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
trizzo:

I cannot create multiple desktops!

Use this forum thread for that:

Multiple workspaces / multiple virtual desktops in Kicksecure 18 (Wayland / labwc) Support
Switching the Wayland compositor used by Kicksecure isn’t supported currently. Supporting a Wayland compositor is much more involved than supporting a window manager under X11, because the compositor is both the window manager and the display server. Of all the desktop environments in Kicksecure, LXQt was the only one light enough to be suitable for Kicksecure and that had mature enough Wayland support, and the best-supported compositor for LXQt is labwc, so that’s what we went with. (For simila…

item.title: Ram-wipe no longer functional in Kicksecure 18?
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
1 issue = 1 forum thread please.

These are very different issues and will create a mess if discussed in the same forum thread. So I’ll just focus on the first one.

trizzo:
  • Ram-Wipe no longer works

“No longer works” is very vague. How do you conclude that it does no works?

Proper bug report as per Sample Bug Report required.

But as for ram-wipe. let me wild guess… You’re used to seeing lots of output (by sdmem) during shut down but cannot see that anymore?

No. That’s invalid methodology. ram-wipe nowadays works differently and more efficiently. There is no more need to use sdmem.

Related ram-wipe user documentation:

Kicksecure – 29 Nov 25

ram-wipe - Wipe RAM on shutdown and reboot

Wipe RAM at shutdown to prevent information extraction from memory. ram-wipe, a software project designed to defend against RAM extraction attacks by wiping a computer's RAM clean during shutdown or restart. This provides an additional layer of...

Related ram-wipe developer documentation:

Kicksecure – 30 Nov 25

RAM Wipe Development Notes

ram-wipe - Implementation notes.

github.com

GitHub - zarhus/ram-dump-efi: Minimalistic application to dump RAM from EFI,...

Minimalistic application to dump RAM from EFI, based on Dasharo/ram-remanence-tester

blog.3mdeb.com

Thoughts dereferenced from the scratchpad noise. | ram-wipe: Further analysis

item.title: Ram-wipe no longer functional in Kicksecure 18?
item.dc:creator: @trizzo
item.description:
Hi. I just upgraded to Kicksecure 18. It looks amazing! Well done guys!

However I have many issues that I’ll list below:

  1. Ram-Wipe no longer works
  2. Start up sequence is weird, loops around and around until I type my passphrase in, then it works
  3. I cannot create multiple desktops! Something I need personally
  4. The panel doesn’t intelligently hide when I select the option for it to hide when a window overlaps.

Other than these few things I’ve noticed, it is all in all pretty good!

Cheers guys, I hope these problems can be fixed soon

item.title: No LibreOffice Included? (18.0.8.7 Feedback)

This is a rather difficult balance to strike.

Here in this forum thread is a request for “more”.

Other users are requesting “less”:
Whonix should bundle less pre-installed programs (minimal images) - Development - Whonix Forum

item.dc:creator: @Patrick

item.title: Kicksecure IPv6 Default Settings (18.0.8.7 Feedback)
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description: Question “Does Disabling IPv6 reduce Tor Anonymity set?” is unspecific to Kicksecure in so far as the very same question could be asked when using Debian. Kicksecure doesn’t introduce a relevant difference. Therefore the answer would also be the same. Therefore this question is best redirected at the Tor community as per Self Support First Policy for Kicksecure.

item.title: Problems with Kicksecure-18 in Qubes OS (usbguard in sys-qubes)
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
arraybolt3:

I don’t really understand why disabling the service in the template isn’t working. Will test here and document what needs to be done to turn it off if the steps end up being harder than a simple sudo systemctl disable usbguard.service command.

Found the issue, usbguard-dbus.service also needs disabled with sudo systemctl disable usbguard-dbus.service. Once both this and usbguard.service are disabled, USB devices are transparently accepted in a Kicksecure-based sys-usb.

Documented at:

Kicksecure – 11 Jan 26

USBGuard - protect your computer against rogue USB devices

Enable and disable USBGuard on Kicksecure.

item.title: No battery Status Indicator? (18.0.8.7 Feedback)
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description: Sounds like a bug, will look into it.

item.title: Kicksecure Removable Media plugin (18.0.8.7 Feedback)
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
exfil:

I also saw and took note of:

[Volume]
AutoRun=true
MountOnStartup=true
MountRemovable=true

~/.config/pcmanfm-qt/lxqt/settings.conf should that be disabled or would that effect users like myself that fully installed the system on USB or SD card?

This should be disabled, and you can manually disable it. See:

Whonix Forum – 28 Dec 25

Disk & USB Automount in Kicksecure

Support
status_closed_issue_implemented

Will be fixed in version 18.0.9.9 (and above). To change this setting manually before a newer version is released: ~/.config/pcmanfm-qt/default/settings.conf Settings: MountOnStartup=false MountRemovable=false Developer information:

item.title: No LibreOffice Included? (18.0.8.7 Feedback)
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description: 318 MB is a lot; our ISO is around 1244 MB at the moment, and while squashfs compression would reduce the size of LibreOffice a lot, it’s still quite a bit of additional bytes (which can make a big difference when it comes to download costs, though I don’t know how much the server hosting costs). It’s simple enough to install the way you did it, some users will want other components like Calc, Draw, Impress, etc. and many users likely don’t have a use for it.

item.title: Emerg-shutdown not showing any messages at shutdown? (18.0.8.7 Feedback)
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
exfil:

Is this the intended behavior? If not, could we consider adding a brief display message before the shutdown occurs?

This is the intended behavior indeed.

Adding a display message (or any pause of any kind) would be a security hazard for the threat model emerg-shutdown is meant to defend against. Imagine you’re using Kicksecure from an external USB drive, and you’re using it to do something a physically proximate adversary doesn’t like. As you’re doing this work, the adversary suddenly breaks open the door to the room you’re in and starts walking toward you quickly. At this point one of your primary concerns is turning off the computer as quickly as possible so that all traces of what you were doing are erased. Every millisecond counts in this scenario, so emerg-shutdown is designed to power off the computer with all haste. It doesn’t make any attempt to save unsaved data, sync filesystems, warn the user of what’s going to happen, etc. it just* tells the kernel to cut power to the system as quickly as it can.

*well, almost; to work around kernel bugs that can result in a kernel panic during shutdown, emerg-shutdown switches to an unused TTY first. This is necessary to keep the system from hanging or rebooting instead of shutting down if you’re using Intel graphics, at least on some systems.

More about emerg-shutdown’s threat model, implementation, and usage is here:

Kicksecure – 19 Dec 25

emerg-shutdown - Instantly Power Off the System

emerg-shutdown immediately and forcibly powers off the system if the boot drive is removed or a "panic" key combo is pressed. When used in combination with full disk encryption, it is a powerful tool to prevent data theft by physically present...

item.title: Cleaner Default Desktop (18.0.8.7 Feedback)
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
I’d prefer to not mess with the desktop too much unless there’s a practical reason to do so. Some people would prefer an iconless desktop, some others might prefer a desktop with desktop shortcuts for accessing the home folder, etc. If we do make an aesthetic change, it should probably be in response to poll feedback so that we know that we’re making a change that is generally beneficial to our userbase.

exfil:

Oh and one more thing, I’m not sure whether it’s possible to unintentionally drag the Home folder shortcut into a browser window. Imagine an user accidentally dropping it onto an upload field, suddenly they’re trying to upload their entire home directory. Would that scenario even be possible?

Tested it in a VM just now. It looks like this is not possible; if I drag-n-drop the “user” desktop shortcut into a file sharing website, it ends up uploading a single small file named user-home.desktop, not my entire home folder. Screenshot:

The contents of this file are:

[Desktop Entry]
Type=Application
Exec=pcmanfm-qt /home/user
Icon=user-home
Name=user

(Note, I have no idea how trustworthy “Limewire” is, I found them in Google search results. This was done in a VM with no sensitive information and no shared folders. I just used them as an example since they were convenient and didn’t require me to sign up for anything to test this.)

item.title: Problems with Kicksecure-18 in Qubes OS (usbguard in sys-qubes)
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
Are you not getting notifications when the adapter is blocked? If you are, you can immediately allow the adapter by clicking the “Allow” button (or whatever it’s called, I don’t remember at the moment) in the notification popup.

I don’t really understand why disabling the service in the template isn’t working. Will test here and document what needs to be done to turn it off if the steps end up being harder than a simple sudo systemctl disable usbguard.service command.

item.title: Cant install chromium browser (browser-choice)
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description: This worked for me the last time I tried it. Do you have a password set on the sysmaint account? If so, maybe the password authentication window was hiding underneath the browser-choice window.

item.title: System Sound Volume at 100% Post Install (18.0.8.7 Feedback)
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description: OK, so probably a quirk of how Debian’s Pipewire and your system’s firmware interact I’m guessing. I’ll apply my “set to 50% one time” fix, that should take care of this.

item.title: Cleaner Default Desktop (18.0.8.7 Feedback)
item.dc:creator: @exfil
item.description:
Installation Details

Version: Kicksecure 18.0.8.7

Install medium: Sandisk USB (Baremetal no virtualization)

Partition format: ext4 (auto-formatted) + LUKS

Bios: Coreboot

I’m a big fan of the clean desktop background, nice and simple! That said, I think the default layout could feel even tidier if we removed a few of the pre‑installed shortcuts: the Computer, Trash, and Home (user) folder shortcuts to be exact.

Leaving the Home folder icon in place is fine, but dropping it would give the desktop an even sleeker look, at least in my opinion. Just a bit of feedback from my side.

Oh and one more thing, I’m not sure whether it’s possible to unintentionally drag the Home folder shortcut into a browser window. Imagine an user accidentally dropping it onto an upload field, suddenly they’re trying to upload their entire home directory. Would that scenario even be possible?

item.title: Kicksecure IPv6 Default Settings (18.0.8.7 Feedback)
item.dc:creator: @exfil
item.description:
Patrick:
exfil:

1. Does Disabling IPv6 reduce Tor Anonymity set?

Unspecific to Kicksecure:

Well kinda since Kicksecure ships the tor daemon for updates and sdwdate…but like you stated IPv6 is not disabled by default so it wouldn’t effect that point

item.title: Kicksecure IPv6 Default Settings (18.0.8.7 Feedback)
item.dc:creator: @exfil
item.description:
arraybolt3:

Not sure, research in this area would be welcome if a contributor is interested in working on it. My experience with IPv6 automatic address assignment is mostly with SLAAC, so I don’t have much insight into what can be done with DHCPv6.

There’s gotta be some configuration way? But then again NetworkManager amiright lol like just how its hardcoded to list SSID’s alphabetically with no option to list by signal strength. Atleast I haven’t found any such option. Something I noticed today when looking for my network in the wave of signals.

item.title: Cant install chromium browser (browser-choice)
item.dc:creator: @exfil
item.description:
Installation Details

Version: Kicksecure 18.0.8.7

Install medium: Sandisk USB

Partition format: ext4 (auto-formatted) + LUKS

Bios: Coreboot

Hey folks,

I recently gave Brave a spin and the browser‑choice panel worked flawlessly, very cool thanks!

However, when I tried to install Chromium through the same panel, it stalled for several minutes with no progress shown in the terminal. I restarted the process a few times, but the result was the same: a blank, black screen.

The only method that finally succeeded was a manual installation sudo apt install --no-recommends chromium chromium-sandbox

The installation is quite long for chromium as opposed for Brave. Could this be a Wayland related issue? When I install Chromium manually, I see status updates, but the browser‑choice UI gives me nothing but darkness in the term emulator.

item.title: No LibreOffice Included? (18.0.8.7 Feedback)
item.dc:creator: @exfil
item.description:
Installation Details

Version: Kicksecure 18.0.8.7

Install medium: Sandisk USB (Baremetal no virtualization)

Partition format: ext4 (auto-formatted) + LUKS

Bios: Coreboot

So I noticed LibreOffice is not packaged with Kicksecure?

Please bundle a minimal LibreOffice installation with the most common language packs for North‑American and European users, plus dictionary and thesaurus plug‑ins.

sudo apt install --no-install-recommends \
    libreoffice-writer \
    libreoffice-l10-en-us \
    hungspell-us-en-us \
    mythes-en-us

This is how I installed LibreOffice with document editor alone minimally with dictionary/thesaurus plugin dependency for English only.

(Anyone following along can use the installation command (minimal writer‑only setup, English only above)

For the distro to include all packs with a wildcard like libreoffice-l10-* would increase size too much so which I would assume is why it wasn’t included to keep ISO size small. With english packs alone for my minimal install it was 150 318MB. Where as if you choose more then english it would be 400MB-600MB roughly I would suppose.

item.title: No battery Status Indicator? (18.0.8.7 Feedback)
item.dc:creator: @exfil
item.description:
Installation Details

Version: Kicksecure 18.0.8.7

Install medium: Sandisk USB (Baremetal no virtualization)

Partition format: ext4 (auto-formatted) + LUKS

Bios: Coreboot

I noticed that neither sysmaint nor user displayed a battery indicator. As a laptop user, that icon is essential when I’m installing software or applying updates.

Below are the terminal checks I ran:

[user ~]% systemctl --user status upower
Unit upower.service could not be found.
zsh: exit 4     systemctl --user status upower
[user ~]% qdbus org.lxqt.panel /org/lxqt/Panel1 
zsh: command not found: qdbus
zsh: exit 127   qdbus org.lxqt.panel /org/lxqt/Panel1
[user ~]% dbus-send --session --dest=org.freedesktop.UPower --print-reply /org/freedesktop/UPower org.freedesktop.DBus.Introspectable.Introspect

Error org.freedesktop.DBus.Error.ServiceUnknown: The name org.freedesktop.UPower was not provided by any .service files
zsh: exit 1     dbus-send --session --dest=org.freedesktop.UPower --print-reply  
[user ~]%

First, I inspected the upower service in sysmaint. It reported “active but disabled,” so I enabled it sudo systemctl enable upower and rebooted into the user session.

Even after that, the power indicator remained elusive, and the panel lacked a battery widget entirely.

The workaround? I opened Power Management, ticked Enable Battery Watcher, and finally got something to appear at the top of the panel. It isn’t the classic battery icon, but it does show the charging state e.g., “Charging (100 %), to full 0 minute(s).” Unfortunately, the physical LED on my laptop is NOT green despite it saying 100 % with 0 minutes remaining lol

Any reason why the widget is not installed? Security reasons? Wayland issues?

item.title: Add a “Privacy Settings” Section to Kicksecure’s System‑Maintenance Panel
item.dc:creator: @exfil
item.description:
Kicksecure’s primary focus is rock solid security out of the box, and its close ties to Whonix and the wider privacy community are impossible to ignore. In practice, today’s Kicksecure installation feels much like a Whonix workstation acting as the host, with a handful of extra hardening tweaks.

Because many Kicksecure users (myself included) come from Whonix or other privacy centric ecosystems communities, a consolidated Privacy panel would be a welcome addition. It would give privacy focused users a single place to fine tune their system after install (post install), while preserving the security first and user choice philosophy that defines Kicksecure. This would help point users that ask repeated questions “about why is xyz privacy feature or setting not in Kicksecure” to go there to enable them if they need them.

Most mainstream distributions ship a “Privacy” section in settings in their DE, but those menus rarely expose the full set of controls that power users expect. Adding a dedicated privacy section to the sysmaint‑panel would let users adjust these options on demand, without enabling them by default. This also benefits anyone who runs Kicksecure as the host OS and then layers Whonix (or another VM) on top via VirtualBox or KVM.

Below is idea for each item could be presented as a simple checkbox (or switch) that toggles the corresponding setting:

[ ] Set the system timezone to UTC
[ ] Enable/Disabe Boot Clock Randomization
[ ] Fully Disable Bluetooth
[ ] Enable/Disable MAC address spoofing
[ ] Disable sending hostname with DHCP requests (reduces some fingerprintability when combined with mac spoofing)
[ ] Activate/Deactivate IPv6 Privacy Extensions
[ ] Check if GeoClue is removed and install dummy dependencies

What are your thoughts on this? Would is blur the line between Kicksecure and Whonix too much or would it be a nice addition?

item.title: Problems with Kicksecure-18 in Qubes OS (usbguard in sys-qubes)
item.dc:creator: @linuxer
item.description:
Hello. I’m not a very advanced user and I’ve run into difficulties with kicksecure‑18 in Qubes. I want to set up sys‑net, sys‑firewall, and sys‑usb on a Kicksecure template. I’m using a USB‑Wi‑Fi adapter, and usbguard always blocks it. I disabled usbguard.service in Kicksecure template, but that didn’t help - Wi‑Fi adapter is still blocked. Could you write a wiki instruction for handling cases like this?

I also keep receiving notifications:
denied: sdwdate-gui.connectCheck from sys‑usb (sys‑firewall, sys‑net) to sys‑whonix.
upd. It seems I’ve found a solution in the wiki for denied: sdwdate-gui.connectCheck

Kicksecure – 7 Jan 26

Kicksecure for Qubes

Using Kicksecure-Qubes

item.title: Systemcheck shows FDE absent in Live Mode (18.0.8.7 Feedback)
item.dc:creator: @exfil
item.description:
Patrick:

systemcheck could be tailored to be non-intrusive, more suitable in live mode.

Now you got me confused as to what I was asking lol I guess maybe not show errors for things that user cant run due to user-sysmaint-split “sudo commands”. Will have to dig into the meat and potatos of what it all does in the wiki/code.

Patrick:

systemcheck could be tailored to be non-intrusive, more suitable in live mode.

Yeah I think that’s what I was getting at. This thread shouldn’t be high priority just my personal thoughts up installation and use. Like I see smartmontools is bundeled in Kicksecure, not sure which thing its for and if that plays role any checks like you mentioned. Really nice to have it included but it fails for USER on persistent mode despite getting it set for my Sandisk Cruiser (sudo smartctl -d scsi -s on /dev/sda). Failing drives such a pain if you have had them, which I have btw (unrelated to kicksecure). Nice to have it setup if I can with sendmail to send email notifying you your drive is gonna fail. Might be good for documentation on setting that up. Useful for server users despite them having RAID setup, or just a desktop user.

item.title: Kicksecure Removable Media plugin (18.0.8.7 Feedback)
item.dc:creator: @exfil
item.description:
It does look like you can’t hide system volumes?

I tried hidding the Network tab in PCManFM-Qt with luck by trying to add:

[Places]
HiddenPlaces=network;

in ~/.config/pcmanfm-qt/default/settings.conf and ~/.config/pcmanfm-qt/lxqt/settings.conf but manually check “hide” in the GUI worked but we should figure out how to globally set it for the conf

I also saw and took note of:

[Volume]
AutoRun=true
MountOnStartup=true
MountRemovable=true

~/.config/pcmanfm-qt/lxqt/settings.conf should that be disabled or would that effect users like myself that fully installed the system on USB or SD card?

item.title: Emerg-shutdown not showing any messages at shutdown? (18.0.8.7 Feedback)
item.dc:creator: @exfil
item.description:
Installation Details

Version: 18.0.8.7 Feedback

Install medium: Sandisk USB (Baremetal no virtualization)

Partition format: ext4 (auto-formatted) + LUKS

BIOS: Coreboot

Hi everyone,

I’m a bit puzzled by the way emerg‑shutdown operates in both persistence and live modes when I’m using a USB thumb drive. I want to report that it does work in both modes for my installation. The question at hand is when I unplug the drive, the system simply powers off without displaying any on screen notification.

Is this the intended behavior? If not, could we consider adding a brief display message before the shutdown occurs?

Thanks for your help!

P.S. Very much pleased so far good work!

Or I tried to fix problem myself and deleted something files (I was using AI for assistance - I’ve never worked with LXQt). Right now all of my appVMs switch keyboard layouts correctly and have two languages, except for Kicksecure/Whonix. I tried to find a temporary workaround for this problem – could you help me?

I also checked whonix‑workstation template - file is present. So problem with file must have been some mistake on my part. I didn’t reinstall whonix‑workstation and qubes-gui-agent in whonix

item.title: Add second language to layout
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
The paste is hard to read. Next time, please use Code Tags.

Patrick:

Try to check your system using debsums.

sudo debsums --silent --all

You can ignore most modified files in /etc and missing files in /boot.

You didn’t provide this. So I don’t know how broken your Template is. This is highly unexpected. I don’t know how you could end up without file /usr/lib/qubes/qubes-keymap.sh unless you manually deleted it?

(No. Not a indicator of compromise. Valid Compromise Indicators versus Invalid Compromise Indicators)

The way to fix this is by investigating why the Template was broken in this way or re-installing the Template. Because if this strange missing file issue can happen, then you can also have lots of other strange follow-up issues.
